definition: lit. shoes and slippers muddled together (idiom); fig. many guests come and go/a lively party
shoe/to tread on
shoe/slipper
to hand over/to deliver/to pay (money)/to turn over/to make friends/to intersect (lines)/variant of 跤[jiao1]
mistake/wrong/bad/interlocking/complex/to grind/to polish/to alternate/to stagger/to miss/to let slip/to evade/to inlay with gold or silver
surname Cuo
lit. a chicken and a bottle of wine (idiom); fig. ready to make an offering to the deceased, or to entertain guests
lit. almanac from years back (idiom)/obsolete practice/old-fashioned principle
cow and famous steed at the same trough (idiom); fig. the common and the great are treated alike
feast/banquet
to host a banquet
in hemp cloth and with a leather belt/poorly dressed
lit. to buy smiles to seek happiness/abandon oneself to the pleasures of the flesh (idiom)
lit. the old man lost his horse, but it all turned out for the best (idiom)/fig. a blessing in disguise/it's an ill wind that blows nobody any good
without news from sb (idiom)
to live in luxury/lit. to ride a solid carriage pulled by fat horses
mounted escort
Danger appears where many harmful factors exist. (idiom)
brothel
lit. clouds scatter, wind flows (idiom); the crisis settles down/people disperse home/things return to normal
out of tune/marital discord, cf qin and se 琴瑟, two string instruments as symbol of marital harmony
to beg while playing the xiao 箫 (mouth organ)/cf Wu Zixu 伍子胥, destitute refugee from Chu 楚, busked in Wu town c. 520 BC, then became a powerful politician
